definitions: having left one's job and ceased to work, typically upon reaching the age limit
removed from active service or use, no longer operational
examples: The retired teacher volunteers at the library every week
My retired parents travel around the country in their RV
The retired battleship now serves as a floating museum
These retired train models are displayed in the transport museum

definitions: tending to avoid company or notice; reserved and preferring to remain unnoticed
in the process of leaving one's job permanently, typically due to age
examples: Despite her talent, she has a retiring personality that keeps her from the spotlight
The retiring nature of the scientist contrasted with his groundbreaking discoveries
The retiring CEO will hand over responsibilities next month
Several retiring employees received gold watches at the ceremony

definitions: capable of being drawn back or in; designed to be pulled back into a housing or casing
examples: The pen has a retractable tip that clicks in and out
Stadium seats with retractable roofs protect fans from rain
The cat's retractable claws help it climb trees efficiently
This knife features a retractable blade for safety

definitions: drawn back or pulled in from an extended position or state
formally withdrawn or taken back, especially referring to a statement or accusation
examples: The retracted landing gear allowed the plane to fly more efficiently
The turtle's retracted head was barely visible in its shell
The newspaper published a retracted statement about the false allegations
His retracted confession raised questions about the investigation

definitions: relating to or reviving the styles, designs, or fashions from the recent past
examples: She decorated her apartment with retro furniture from the 1960s
The band's retro sound recalls the classic rock of the seventies
His retro clothing style makes him stand out at modern parties
The diner has a retro aesthetic with chrome fixtures and vinyl booths

definitions: taking effect from a date in the past, especially applying to past events or periods
examples: The salary increase will be retroactive to January first
Congress passed retroactive tax legislation affecting last year's returns
The court's retroactive ruling changed the legal status of previous cases
Employees received retroactive pay for overtime worked months ago

definitions: directed or moving backward, opposite to the usual or forward direction
reverting to an inferior or less developed state; showing decline or deterioration
examples: Mercury appears to have retrograde motion several times each year
The planet's retrograde orbit puzzled astronomers for decades
The new policy represents a retrograde step for civil rights
Critics called the decision retrograde and harmful to progress

definitions: looking back on or dealing with past events, situations, or artistic works
examples: The museum organized a retrospective exhibition of her paintings
His retrospective analysis revealed patterns missed at the time
The documentary takes a retrospective look at the band's career
Retrospective studies examined patient records from previous decades

definitions: coming back to a place, position, or situation after being away
examples: Returning students must register for classes by next Friday
The returning champion defended her title successfully
Returning customers receive a ten percent discount on purchases
Many returning soldiers struggled to adjust to civilian life

definitions: capable of being used again or repeatedly after appropriate treatment or processing
examples: She carries reusable shopping bags to reduce plastic waste
The company switched to reusable containers for shipping products
These reusable water bottles help minimize environmental impact
Hospitals are adopting more reusable medical equipment to cut costs

definitions: making interesting or significant information known; giving insight into something hidden
allowing more of the body to be seen than is usual; showing a lot of skin
examples: Her revealing comments about the company shocked the board members
The investigation uncovered revealing documents about the conspiracy
She wore a revealing dress to the summer party
The revealing swimsuit designs attracted controversy at the fashion show

definitions: providing a surprising or previously unknown insight; making something dramatically clearer
examples: The biography contained revelatory details about the artist's early life
Her revelatory performance changed how critics viewed her abilities
The scientist's revelatory findings transformed our understanding of genetics
Reading his private letters was a revelatory experience for historians

definitions: regarded with deep respect, admiration, and often religious or spiritual veneration
examples: The revered elder shared wisdom with the younger generation
She became a revered figure in the civil rights movement
The revered temple attracts thousands of pilgrims each year
His revered status in the community made him a natural mediator

definitions: deserving or commanding deep respect and reverence; worthy of veneration
used as a title for members of the clergy, especially Protestant ministers
examples: The reverend gentleman commanded respect from all who met him
Her reverend manner during the ceremony impressed the congregation
Reverend Smith will conduct the Sunday morning service
The Reverend Doctor Martin Luther King Jr. led the march

definitions: feeling or showing deep and solemn respect, often with religious overtones
examples: The crowd maintained a reverent silence during the memorial service
She approached the ancient artifact with reverent care
His reverent tone reflected the sacredness of the ceremony
Students showed reverent attention during the professor's final lecture

definitions: going in or turned toward the opposite direction or position from usual
relating to or denoting the back or rear side of something
examples: The reverse gear helps drivers back out of parking spaces
Scientists studied the reverse flow of the ocean current
Check the reverse side of the document for additional information
The reverse image in the mirror confused the child

definitions: turned around to face or move in the opposite direction or position
changed completely to the opposite condition, decision, or arrangement
examples: The reversed image in the photograph confused viewers initially
Traffic followed a reversed pattern during the special event
The court's reversed decision gave hope to the defendants
Their reversed roles in the play added comedy to the performance

definitions: able to be turned the other way around or changed to the opposite
able to be worn or used with either side as the outer surface
examples: The chemical reaction is reversible under certain conditions
Brain damage from the stroke proved to be partially reversible
She bought a reversible jacket with different colors on each side
The reversible belt matches both brown and black shoes

definitions: returning to a previous state, condition, practice, or belief after a period of change
examples: The reverting software automatically restored the previous settings
Reverting behavior patterns emerged under stress
The reverting ownership clause activated after the lease expired
His reverting symptoms worried the medical team

definitions: examined and corrected or updated to improve accuracy, clarity, or completeness
examples: The revised edition includes new chapters and updated statistics
Students must submit their revised essays by Friday
The company announced revised profit forecasts for the quarter
Her revised opinion reflected new evidence in the case

definitions: imbued with new life, energy, or vigor; restored to a better or more active state
examples: The revitalised downtown area attracts tourists and locals alike
Her revitalised career surprised industry observers
The revitalised team won their next five matches consecutively
A revitalised economy brought hope to the struggling region

definitions: imbued with new life, energy, or vigor; restored to a better or more active state
examples: The revitalized neighborhood features new shops and restaurants
His revitalized interest in painting produced stunning new works
The revitalized company launched innovative products successfully
A revitalized democracy emerged after years of struggle

definitions: imparting new life, energy, or vigor; having a restorative or refreshing effect
examples: The revitalizing effects of the vacation lasted for weeks
She found the mountain air revitalizing after months in the city
A revitalizing facial treatment left her skin glowing
The revitalizing economic policies attracted foreign investment

definitions: restored to life, consciousness, or vigor from apparent death or unconsciousness
renewed or restored after a period of decline, neglect, or obscurity
examples: The revived patient opened her eyes after receiving emergency treatment
Paramedics successfully revived the drowning victim
The revived musical enjoyed a successful run on Broadway
His revived enthusiasm for the project motivated the entire team

definitions: bringing back to life, consciousness, health, or vigor; having a restorative effect
examples: The reviving rain ended the long drought
A reviving cup of coffee helped her finish the report
The reviving influence of young artists transformed the gallery
Reviving traditional crafts has become her life's mission

definitions: causing intense disgust or strong feelings of repulsion; extremely unpleasant or offensive
examples: The revolting smell from the garbage made everyone leave the room
She found his table manners absolutely revolting
The revolting conditions in the prison shocked human rights inspectors
That revolting display of greed disgusted the other shareholders

definitions: involving or causing a complete or dramatic change; radically new or innovative
relating to or supporting political revolution; engaged in or promoting revolution
examples: Her revolutionary approach to teaching transformed education methods
The revolutionary technology changed how people communicate globally
Revolutionary forces occupied the capital city last night
His revolutionary writings inspired movements across Latin America

definitions: had as the central or most important feature or element; was focused on
examples: Their revolved lifestyle around their children's activities consumed all their time
The revolved discussion around budget cuts dominated the meeting
His revolved world around music influenced every decision he made
The revolved plot around revenge drove the entire narrative

definitions: providing satisfaction, gratification, or a sense of achievement; worthwhile and fulfilling
examples: Teaching children to read is an incredibly rewarding experience
She found volunteer work more rewarding than her corporate job
The challenging project proved rewarding despite initial difficulties
Building your own furniture can be both difficult and rewarding

definitions: relating to the art of effective speaking or writing, especially using figurative language
asked merely for effect with no answer expected or sought
examples: Her rhetorical skills made her an excellent debater
The speech employed various rhetorical devices to persuade listeners
He posed a rhetorical question to emphasize his point
Her rhetorical flourishes impressed the audience but lacked substance

definitions: relating to or caused by rheumatism; affecting joints and connective tissues with pain and stiffness
examples: Her rheumatic pains worsen during cold, damp weather
The doctor prescribed medication for his rheumatic condition
Rheumatic fever can cause serious heart complications if untreated
The elderly woman's rheumatic joints made walking difficult

definitions: relating to or affected by rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disorder
examples: Her rheumatoid arthritis requires regular medication and physical therapy
The rheumatoid factor test helps diagnose the autoimmune condition
Rheumatoid nodules developed on his elbows and fingers
Early rheumatoid symptoms include joint stiffness and fatigue

definitions: having or characterized by words with corresponding sounds, especially at line endings
examples: The rhymed couplets gave the poem a musical quality
Children enjoy rhymed stories because they're easier to remember
His rhymed verse followed traditional sonnet structure perfectly
The rhymed lyrics made the song catchy and memorable

definitions: having or producing words with corresponding sounds, especially at the ends of lines
examples: The rhyming dictionary helped her complete the song lyrics
Children love rhyming games that teach language patterns
His rhyming slang confused tourists visiting London
The rhyming pattern follows an ABAB structure throughout

definitions: having or characterized by a strong, regular, repeated pattern of movement or sound
examples: The rhythmic beating of drums filled the concert hall
Her rhythmic breathing indicated she had fallen deeply asleep
The dancers moved in rhythmic patterns across the stage
Rhythmic gymnastics combines dance with athletic movements

definitions: having or characterized by a strong, regular, repeated pattern of movement or sound
examples: The rhythmical swaying of trees hypnotized the observer
Her rhythmical speech pattern made her presentations engaging
The machine produced rhythmical clicking sounds while operating
Students practiced rhythmical exercises to improve their timing

definitions: marked with or having raised lines or ridges running in a regular pattern
examples: She wore a ribbed sweater that kept her warm in winter
The ribbed texture of the fabric provides extra stretch
Ribbed metal roofing offers better drainage than flat surfaces
The shell's ribbed surface helps protect the mollusk inside

definitions: having a great deal of money, resources, or assets; wealthy
containing or providing something in large amounts or high concentration
pleasantly deep, strong, or intense in color, flavor, sound, or smell
examples: The rich businessman donated millions to charity each year
Rich nations should help developing countries improve infrastructure
The soil is rich in minerals essential for plant growth
This dessert is too rich for me to finish
The painting uses rich colors that capture autumn perfectly
Her rich voice filled the concert hall effortlessly

definitions: pierced with many holes, especially from bullets or disease
filled or pervaded with something undesirable, especially problems or errors
examples: The old barn was riddled with bullet holes from hunters
The tree trunk was riddled with woodpecker holes
The report was riddled with errors and had to be rewritten
Their relationship was riddled with mistrust and jealousy

definitions: marked with or formed into raised lines, strips, or bands on a surface
examples: The ridged potato chips provide extra crunch and hold more dip
Her ridged fingernails indicated a possible nutritional deficiency
The ridged bark of the oak tree felt rough to touch
Archaeologists found ridged pottery fragments at the site

definitions: deserving or inviting derision or mockery; absurd, preposterous, or extremely silly
examples: The ridiculous price of the designer handbag shocked everyone
His ridiculous excuse for being late fooled no one
She looked ridiculous wearing a winter coat in summer
The proposal's ridiculous requirements made it impossible to implement

definitions: relating to or characteristic of the Iberian Peninsula, comprising Spain and Portugal
examples: The Iberian Peninsula has a rich history of cultural exchange
Iberian cuisine features olive oil and seafood prominently
The Iberian lynx is one of the world's most endangered cats
Ancient Iberian art shows influences from various Mediterranean cultures

definitions: relating to Iceland, its people, culture, or language
examples: The Icelandic language has remained largely unchanged for centuries
Icelandic horses are known for their unique fifth gait
She studied Icelandic sagas in her medieval literature course
The Icelandic economy depends heavily on fishing and tourism

definitions: relating to the Inca civilization or empire that flourished in Peru before Spanish conquest
examples: Incan architecture demonstrates advanced engineering without modern tools
The Incan road system connected the vast empire efficiently
Machu Picchu remains the most famous Incan archaeological site
Incan agricultural terraces still function in some Andean communities

definitions: relating to India, its peoples, cultures, or languages
relating to the indigenous peoples of the Americas (though this usage is now often considered outdated)
examples: Indian cuisine varies greatly between different regions of the country
The Indian economy has grown rapidly in recent decades
The museum displays Indian artifacts from various North American tribes
Indian reservations maintain sovereign status within the United States

definitions: relating to Indonesia, its peoples, cultures, or languages
examples: Indonesian cuisine reflects the country's diverse cultural influences
The Indonesian archipelago consists of over seventeen thousand islands
She studied Indonesian language to prepare for her trip
Indonesian batik is recognized by UNESCO as cultural heritage

definitions: relating to ancient Ionia, its people, or the Ionian Greeks of Asia Minor
examples: Ionian philosophy profoundly influenced Western thought and science
The Ionian Sea separates Greece from southern Italy
Ionian columns feature distinctive spiral scrolls called volutes
Ancient Ionian cities were centers of learning and culture

definitions: relating to or denoting ions or ionization; having an electric charge
relating to the Ionic order of classical architecture, characterized by scroll-like ornaments
examples: Ionic bonds form between atoms with opposite electrical charges
The ionic solution conducts electricity efficiently
The building features Ionic columns with elegant spiral volutes
Ionic architecture represents one of three classical Greek orders

definitions: relating to Iran (formerly Persia), its people, culture, or languages
examples: Iranian cinema has won numerous international awards recently
The Iranian plateau covers much of western Asia
She studied Iranian history focusing on the Safavid dynasty
Iranian cuisine features rice, kebabs, and aromatic herbs

definitions: relating to Iraq, its people, culture, or Arabic dialect
examples: Iraqi cuisine combines influences from various Middle Eastern traditions
The Iraqi government faces challenges rebuilding after years of conflict
Ancient Iraqi archaeological sites include Babylon and Ur
Iraqi oil reserves are among the largest in the world
